III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A reported threats from other youth to staff and was
subsequently assaulted, there is concern that staff did not properly
protect Youth A.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on
09/04/2024. She stated Youth A informed her that he felt unsafe
after youth tried to fight him, but did not have any other
information to provide.
The Program Director was interviewed on 07/17/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He was aware of
some recent fights between Youth A and other youth and had no
concerns that Youth A’s safety was not being protected. He
remarked that Youth A was placed at the facility on 06/27/2024
and had already had pods moved to try to separate him from other
youth that appeared to be escalating easily with him. Program
Director also recalled directly speaking with Youth A within the last
week and that Youth A did not express to him that he felt unsafe
or that he felt staff were not working to ensure his safety.
The Foster Care Worker for Youth A was interviewed over email
on 07/24/2024. She stated she had received incident reports and
had communicated with Youth A since his placement and did not
have any concerns for his safety at the facility.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/30/2024 during an unannounced
visit to the facility. He recalled one specific instance where other
youth tried to assault him recently by rushing into his room. Youth
A referred to the staff involved, of which he could not remember
specific names, as doing their jobs and immediately
2

intervening. Youth A believed this prevented him from getting
injured or the fight escalating. He also brought up an incident
from the day prior where staff were sitting outside of Youth A’s
room because there was a concern about other youth in the pod
attempting to escalate situations with Youth A. Youth A refused to
identify the other youth and could not name the staff involved. He
stated there had not been any situations where he had felt unsafe
since being placed at the facility, and felt the times that he had
been moved pods was done so with his safety in mind. Youth A
also commented that every day staff provided consequences to
youth, including himself at times, within the facility’s
programming. Youth A remarked the consequences were
consistently provided, but he did not think that those were ever
going to be enough to stop any youth from doing what they
wanted to do.
Youth B was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an unannounced
visit to the facility. He believed that consequences for youth not
following facility rules were consistently applied and that had to
occur often because of a significant amount of negative behavior
from other youth in the program. Youth B felt safe at the program.
Youth B did not comment on any assaults or incidents that he felt
were a result of any lack of staff intervention.
Youth C was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an unannounced
visit to the facility. He stated that youth moving pods was frequent
within the facility, but he believed it was always done in order to
best ensure their safety. Youth C commented that staff are
present and always break up fights. He recalled a recent incident
where he got into a fight himself and as a result was written up for
it. Youth C stated he felt safe at the program.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 02/07/2025. She
reported being familiar with Youth A and his placement at the
facility. Staff 3 recalled many instances when Youth A would
experience escalated behavior directed towards other youth, or
other youth directing the same at him. Staff 3 reported no
concerns that this had ever occurred without proper staff
intervention.
Attempts were made to speak with Staff 4 on 02/05/2025 and
02/07/2025 with no success.
Documentation reviewed:
• Four incident reports regarding Youth A dated 07/14/2024,
07/25/2024 and two on 07/29/2024 were reviewed. All four
3

incident reports documented various staff interventions,
including Staff 3 and Staff 4’s involvement, between Youth
A and other youth as well as for attempts to destroy
property by Youth A.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
to show that the safety of Youth A was not being ensured.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge
of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 was instructed by management to take paperwork and
documentation related to the youth in care, home for it's
completion.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on
09/04/2024. She stated she was aware that staff were taking
paperwork, such as suicide watch forms, home to fill out and had
been informed to do so by Supervisor 2. No other information on
how this was known, or any other details were able to be
provided.
The Program Director was interviewed on 07/17/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He stated no staff
members had brought any concerns to his attention that any
documentation for the program had been taken out of the building
to be completed. The Program Director believed this was unlikely
because of how documentation was organized within the control
rooms of the pods and a general, unwritten practice that staff do
not carry any paperwork around while moving throughout the
4

facility to protect confidentiality and to reduce the risk of
misplacing it.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an
unannounced visit to the facility. She stated she had no concerns
about documentation being taken offsite largely because much of
what staff and supervisors were required to complete was done on
computers. She stated that no one had ever brought it to her
attention this was allegedly occurring.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone on
11/19/2024. She stated she has never had a concern or heard
anything about staff possibly taking paperwork outside of the
building. She referred to the required documentation that was
needed at times, such as overnight watch logs, incident reports,
and suicide watch documentation, as simple to complete in their
nature and that staff normally completed those items before the
end of their shifts as is the normal practice for the facility. She
also stated that it was common place for staff to ask for help if a
documentation task was not being completed. Supervisor 1
stated there were times that a document might not be completed
timely, but that situation would mean it was not taken outside of
the building to be completed. Supervisor 1 was not sure how her
name may have been mentioned as someone who was aware of
this allegation.
Attempts to interview Staff 1 were made on 10/17/2024 and
11/19/2024 with no return contact.
Documentation reviewed:
• New Employee Orientation documentation for Staff 1 was
provided and reviewed. This contained confirmation that
Employee Ethics policy had been reviewed with Staff 1 at
the time of hire.
• Facility Employee Ethics Policy last dated 12/15/2020 was
provided and reviewed. This policy outlined standards of
conduct, including the requirement that staff “shall ensure
the confidentiality of consumers and employees is not
inappropriately disclosed.”
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per staff interviews and
documentation reviewed. There was no evidence found that staff
have taken documentation out of the building.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

Rule Code Program statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff have falsified records regarding supervision of youth by filling
out documentation ahead of time.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on
09/04/2024. No other information on how the information in the
allegations was known was able to be provided other than the
inclusion of Staff 2 as another individual who knew about the
practice of filling out paperwork in advance.
The Program Director was interviewed on 07/17/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. The Program
Director advised that the “pink sheets” referred to in the allegation
were documentation that was performed to capture eyes-on
efforts for youth who had concerns of suicidal ideation. The
Program Director was not aware of any concern that staff had
allegedly filled out the documentation in advance and stated that
no staff members had brought this to his attention.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed on 08/05/2024 during an
unannounced visit to the facility. She stated she had never had a
concern that staff would have been filling out any paperwork in
advance of anything occurring. She believed that any
documentation regarding timed tasks, such as eyes on checks of
youth, would show details such as correct varied times and
sometimes show that multiple staff completed the tasks as the
night went on.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed over the phone on
11/19/2024. She stated that she had never had concern nor was
it ever brought to her attention that documentation was being filled
out in advance of when it was needed. Part of why Supervisor 1
6

stated this was because of her own responsibilities that she
described, working on third shift at times and walking through
each pod every hour to sign off on the documentation being
completed by third shift staff.
An attempt was made to interview Staff 2 over the phone on
11/19/2024 and no contact was made.
Documentation reviewed:
• New Employee Orientation documentation for Supervisor 1
was provided and reviewed. This contained confirmation
that Employee Ethics policy had been reviewed with
Supervisor 1 at the time of hire.
• Facility Employee Ethics Policy last dated 12/15/2020 was
provided and reviewed. This policy outlined standards of
conduct, including the requirement that staff shall “avoid
misrepresentation and respect the truth while engaged in
agency business.”
• Sample “pink sheets” titled Room Monitoring Records were
provided and reviewed. This documentation showed staff
efforts of staff to monitor youth who were considered a
concern for self harm or had expressed suicidal
ideation. No concerns were noted on this documentation.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as staff interviews and
documentation reviewed. There was no evidence found that any
documentation was being filled out in advance of the need for its
completion.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Program statement.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents'
needs, implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of
residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
7

Allegation Room searches are required by facility policy but have not been
completed properly.
Investigation The Complainant was interviewed over the phone on
09/04/2024. She remarked she was unsure of this allegation
being reported because she had never heard of a lack of room
search practices at the facility. The Complainant stated she was
aware of youth who had contraband or unsafe items from inside
the facility found inside of their rooms and stated this only
occurred because room searches were conducted as needed.
The Program Director was interviewed on 07/17/2024 during an
unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility. He remarked that
room searches being conducted because of the concern that
contraband or unsafe items were located inside of them were not
performed frequently. The Program Director clarified that these
were infrequent events not because they were not being
performed but because there was rare concern that youth had
contraband within the facility.
Youth A was interviewed on 07/30/2024 during an unannounced
visit to the facility. He recalled seeing and hearing about other
youth’s rooms being searched on occasion and did not express
concern that this was not occurring as would be needed to ensure
safety.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed separately on 08/05/2024
during an unannounced visit to the facility. They both stated that
room searches happened on occasion and neither expressed
concern that they had not been completed as necessary.
The facility’s Licensee Designee was interviewed over the phone
on 01/24/2025. He reported rare occurrences of room searches at
the facility over the past year. He believed that this was due to
good practices to search youth upon entrance in the facility, as
well as the elimination of items within the facility that could present
safety precautions. He reported that documentation of room
searches would not exist in separate documentation on it’s own,
but would be contained within incident reports related to other
reasons for the documentation.
Documentation Reviewed:
• The facility confirmed on 01/27/2025 that they do not have
written policy regarding room searches.
8

• As of 01/29/2025 the facility could not produce any incident
reports back to the date of the receipt of these allegations
that contained staff activity of room searches.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed. There was no evidence
found that room searches were not being completed as
necessary.
Technical Assistance
If the agency has expectations for staff to complete room checks,
then a written policy pertaining to room searches should be
developed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
